review.title: Generalizing the Role of Determinization in Probabilistic Planning
review.abstract: The stochastic shortest path problem (SSP) is a highly expressive model for probabilistic planning. The computational hardness of SSPs has sparked interest in determinization-based planners that can quickly solve large problems. However, existing methods employ a simplistic approach to determinization. In particular, they ignore the possibility of tailoring the determinization to the specific characteristics of the target domain. In this work we examine this question, by showing that learning a good determinization for a planning domain can be done efficiently and can improve performance. Moreover, we show how to directly incorporate probabilistic reasoning into the planning problem when a good determinization is not sufficient by itself. Based on these insights, we introduce a planner, FF-LAO*, that outperforms state-of-the-art probabilistic planners on several well-known competition benchmarks.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a new perspective on the use of the provision for probabilistic planning, showing that a careful selection of identification methods can exceed the efficiency of state-of-the-art planners. We also presented a new planner, FF-LAO *, which uses the power of classical planning algorithms for calculation efficiency in choosing the determination, but can also argue probabilistically if necessary. We proposed a strategy for selecting a determination that exploits the inherent structure of a given stochastic area. We show that choosing the determination can generalize problems of different sizes, especially in terms of their impact on planning performance (probability of success and expected costs). We compared our approach with modern planners for goal-oriented probability problems, using a set of benchmarks from the International Probabilistic Planning Competition. Our results strongly support the assertion that choosing the provision can lead to significant increases in planning.
